body: @enothereska I have updated the JIRA descrption: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-3941, please let me know if it looks easier to understand now.

@omkreddy @harshach Agree that it is ok to apply this fix now and revisit in KAFKA-3396 since this only returns the same information as the code already does.

Thanks, LGTM. I tweaked the javadoc changes a little and then merged to trunk.

@rajinisivaram, your suggestion makes sense to me. Since the current SaslHandshakeRequest will continue to be supported, it is fair to only add the check once the client needs to use a hypothetical new version of SaslHandshakeRequest (hopefully never).
Thanks @tcrayford. I will take a deeper look tomorrow if Jun doesn't beat me to it. One question: have you given some thought on how we could test these changes?
@ijuma yeah, we have a system that aggrevates these memory leaks when pointed at a Kafka cluster. I can release the new code to it and then watch for leaks like I did previously.
@ijuma or were you talking about adding tests inside the project itself? Unfortunately it seems impossible to tell if a GZIPInputStream is closed.

Could we do the same on the scripts in `/bin` please?

There was two PR doing it which were refused apparently because folks are scared to change those files, I would love to use those scripts on NixOS without hacking them... and I'm not sure fear is a good reason to refuse those changes....
Thanks @ijuma

@ijuma Is there any mechanism that we can set some elapsed-time-threshold in ducktape which then treat the test as failed if that threshold is violated? What are the current settings for producer / consumer performance services?
@guozhangwang, I am not aware of such functionality, but @granders can confirm.
IMO this could benefit from having an associated jira so users could find the issue, change and its impact if there run into this. Otherwise, LGTM.

I am not sure this change is related to the issue described in the jira for [KAFKA-3940](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-3940):

> In Log.loadSegments(), we call dir.mkdirs() w/o checking the return value and just assume the directory will exist after the call. However, if the directory can't be created (e.g. due to no space), we will hit NullPointerException in the next statement, which will be confusing.
LGTM

@rajinisivaram @ijuma sounds like we do not have a strong reason to add special handling for SASL case as of now, and as such the current design for API version checking does not have to change.

@ijuma does this take care of your concern for SASL scenario, if it does I will start looking at other review comments.
@SinghAsDev Yes, worth adding a comment as Rajini suggested.
This is being revoked in order to implement a more generalized and "universal" fix for all such occurrences as mentioned in the Issue.
thanks @hachikuji @ijuma
LGTM

@junrao I just updated the patch to address the latest comments. One thing worth mentioning is that dumping the active time index may be slow because time index requires looking up the offset index. The offset index of the active segment is always the max index size. This will cause the dump log segment tool to create an offset index with a lot of empty index entries in the end so the binary search in this case does not quite work. Also because the active segment is still growing, dumping it may have some race condition and result in false alarm. So I suppose it is fine to assume that people won't dump the active log segment.
@ijuma would you mind reviewing this?
@ijuma would you mind reviewing this?
@guozhangwang there is the timeout for the test, currently set at 600 seconds. If that threshold is violated, test is considered failed.

Hi @swwl1992, this is indeed a bug and good find. Did a few searches in git history, it seems to be introduced as a regression in KAFKA-687 and reflected in KAFKA-871.

LGTM and merged to trunk / 0.10.0 / 0.9.0 / 0.8.2.
Done, it was actually caused by another PR of mine that got merged (#1461) :grin:.

600 seconds seems a bit too high for streams benchmark, could we override this value for this test case specifically?

Anyways, the code itself LGTM to me but I'm not expert in ducktape, so if @ijuma 's happy I'm good to merge it as is (perhaps with overridden test timeout :P)

Seems you are referring to #335 and #557 - neither was refused out of fear, just a security concern raised :) Let's try to bump...

[ BTW, the motivation for this patch was to fix the shebang not being the first line on the scripts, rather than switch to using `/usr/bin/env`, though that also crept in ]
@ijuma mind looking at this minor patch?

@guozhangwang the override is already in place in `streams_performance.py` and the value we
re using by default is 600 `wait_until(lambda: not node.account.alive(pid), timeout_sec=600`. This is an upper bound. If the benchmark completes beforehand then the test finishes before 600.
@enothereska I understand that the test can complete before 600 seconds, but I was just wondering if that value is too high in terms of detecting if the test is running too long?
@enothereska Left two comments on the most recent commit.
Chatted offline about the timeout value, we agree that it can be kept as is now. @granders @ijuma Do you want to take a final look?

I've been thinking about this and I think we should go ahead with this and then look at ways at improving it further once more of the KIP-4 work is in.

I left a few review comments. In addition to that, we should make the change to the log message as per Jason's suggestion.

Also, users can use `listTopics()` or `partitionsFor()` that don't hang as a workaround (Jason's suggestion).
Thanks for the review, I'll update the PR.
@guozhangwang @enothereska
Ok, now we have separate locks per task ID. LGTM.
@enothereska thanks for adding the benchmark - a couple minor comments/questions

Thanks for the PR. Left a couple of minor comments. Also, can you please edit the PR description to simply describe the change (or simply leave it blank if the PR title is enough)? The PR title and PR description are combined to form the commit message in the merged commit.

Ping for review:

Could now figure out why build failed. Any advise?

I discuss this a bit in the jira ([KAFKA-3934](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-3934)) but would like to bring it up here too. 

I am not sure why the existing scripts check for variables with the style:

``` bash
if [ "x$FOO" = "x" ]; then
   export FOO="$FOO_DEFAULT"
fi
```

Instead of something like:

``` bash
export FOO=${FOO-"$FOO_DEFAULT"} 
```

The first example means unset and "" mean the same thing. I am not sure that is favorable behavior, but even that can be achieved in the shorter format. All varieties are covered in this [reference table](http://i.stack.imgur.com/T2Fp8.png).

@junrao Thanks for the review. I have tested the produce and consume performance with the same script we used for KIP-31/32. The producer and consumer performance are the same. 

Our new dev clusters are ready for use now, but I am still waiting for the mirror maker instances, which should be setup by today. I will run the performance test on the real data and test the segment loading and recovery time with more partitions after that.

For system test, I was trying to use the confluent jenkins server before. But it seems that it does not support building against an arbitrary branch anymore. I am setting up a Hudson job to run the system test internally at this point. But that may take some time as I am not familiar with that.
@becketqin, you can use https://jenkins.confluent.io/job/system-test-kafka-branch-builder/
@onurkaraman Thanks, appreciate it. I'm still adding some test cases and polish, but I don't expect it to change significantly (_fingers crossed_).
Nice find @13h3r. Would you mind adding a test case? The jenkins failure seems unrelated.

It would be great to be able to print topologies at two different stages.  If we call print/toString() on the topology builder, then we'd be able to see what the topology looks like at a high level (which sub-topologies read from which topics and write to other topics and what state stores are used).  At this step, the topology is not yet running so we would not see how many tasks or partitions yet but this is still useful.

Calling print/toString() on the running KafkaStreams object it what's already here and can be helpful for seeing how things got scheduled at runtime.  The main issue I have now is knowing when this can be called.  There isn't a callback in KafkaStreams to know if all threads in the JVM have completed initialization.

Thanks @noslowerdna for the review.

@gwenshap @ijuma @junrao I am tagging you since you were the latest committers to this file: ReplicaFetcherThread.scala do you think we can land this simple patch?

Thanks for the PR, merged to trunk and 0.10.0 branches.

The PR description seems a bit misleading. We talk of validation of valid input, but it seems to me that we don't do any validation apart from setting the type of the parameter (previously `Integer` and now `String`). Is that right? Have we checked that the user gets an appropriate and friendly error if they pass an invalid parameter with the new code?
Thanks for the PR, merged to trunk and 0.10.0 branches.
Still working on some test to be added.
Closed in favor of https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/1636

The issue of knowing when Kafka Streams is up can be deferred to another JIRA.
Thanks for the update @ijuma. LGTM

That's right, what I meant by validation was verifying that the input type is a string and not an integer. I'll try to make this more clear in the description.

With the new code, if I provide any input other than those accepted I get this error:

```
org.apache.kafka.common.config.ConfigException: Invalid value ... for configuration acks: String must be one of: all, -1, 0, 1
    at org.apache.kafka.common.config.ConfigDef$ValidString.ensureValid(ConfigDef.java:827)
    at org.apache.kafka.common.config.ConfigDef.parse(ConfigDef.java:427)
    at org.apache.kafka.common.config.AbstractConfig.<init>(AbstractConfig.java:56)
    at org.apache.kafka.common.config.AbstractConfig.<init>(AbstractConfig.java:63)
    at org.apache.kafka.clients.producer.ProducerConfig.<init>(ProducerConfig.java:337)
    at org.apache.kafka.clients.producer.KafkaProducer.<init>(KafkaProducer.java:188)
    at kafka.producer.NewShinyProducer.<init>(BaseProducer.scala:40)
    at kafka.tools.ConsoleProducer$.main(ConsoleProducer.scala:45)
    at kafka.tools.ConsoleProducer.main(ConsoleProducer.scala)
```
LGTM. Merged to trunk and cherry picked to 0.10.0.
